The booking and payment was simple and easy to complete, which set the tour apart from other Buenos Aires attractions even before the tour started. The day of the tour we arrived at the meeting point, the first restaurant, a neighorhood empanada and pizza shop near the San Telmo market. That day we were a total of 8 plus our local guide. After being given an overview of what we were going to do, we delved into the food, starting with a fantastic empanada fresh from the oven. Next we were given a brief tour of the San Telmo market and told its history. We exited through the far end and went to a small stand for a street food of Argentina, the chorizopan sandwich paired with chimichurri sauce, both excellent. The main stop was just a couple blocks away, a parilla where we had incredibly flavorful sirloin steak, grilled provolone cheese, and a very nice malbec wine. We finished up with an artisan ice cream. We really enjoyed the tour. The guide really added to the experience with their insights into the foods, the culture and recommendations, and most of all having completed the leg work in trying many restaurants to decide on the ones we visited. Keep in mind that they give a significant amount of food, so come hungry.

Nice way to have a long lunch. My husband and I went on this tour in Palermo. We had been staying in Palermo for a week, but hadn't explored this northern area yet. There were four of us on the tour including the guide. it was nice to have a small group. We started with a choripan, the best we'd had in Buenos Aires so far! This was followed by a steak empanada (delicious!), and then cheese, steak, salad and wine at a secret parrilla that is very popular with locals. The food was definitely tasty! We then followed through with some amazing ice cream. I can definitely recommend doing the tour, it's a great way to spend three hours.

An absolute highlight!. We loved this tourFood is such an important part of our travels - and although we were armed with a long list of restaurant recommendations and not enough days - we thought we'd start with this tour. It didn't disappoint !Santiago and Sol felt like old friends - warm welcoming and full of infornation about the food and wine of Argentina - both historically and locally plus great recommendations and advice about BA generally and the food scene in particular We went to local off the beaten track places - each place and experience special and unique and delicious . We don't normally do tours- love to explore ourselves - but we all loved this tour and it just added to the best eating experiences we had of BA - highly recommend

Great guide and cultural insights. This was one of the highlights of my time in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The food was delicious and all the spots chosen felt authentic and off the tourist trail. The local guide, Sol, was invaluable in explaining cultural differences and traditions. This alone made the tour well worth the price.

Great Food, limited tour. This was a great foodie experience in Buenos Aires. The secret parrilla was really great, a memorable experience from our trip. The food, including the final stop for gelato, was top shelf. The woman who lead our tour was very nice.The downside is it truly is an eating tour - four back to back stops for food including a huge meal at the secret Parrilla. Two straight hours of eating with nothing in between. It would have been nicer to get a tour of the neighborhood so there was some walking in between the food stops and you could learn about the area.Come hungry and be prepared to eat...a lot.

Mmmm...steak. But wait, there's more!. When we arrived at the first restaurant on David's tour of Las Cañitas (Palermo), he handed us a list of restaurant and bar recommendations (in addition to the places that we were visiting during the tour). My advice: hold on to that list! David's passion for good food and wine is evident well beyond the four establishments he takes you to on the tour, and we quickly realized that cuisine in Buenos Aires is more than just steak and malbec...and remember to ask him about Frank's (thanks for the tip, David)!

Come Hungry, Leave Happy!. We went on the Parrilla tour with David a few weeks ago. The first restaurant that we all met at was a delicious mom and pop shop that we never would have found on our own. David accommodated our dietary restrictions and was still able to introduce us to an authentic meal. We then went on to have empanadas. Although it would have been nice to take a seat while eating them as opposed to scarfing them down on the street, they tasted amazing and really...that was the whole point of the tour! We were then taken to a secret restaurant that served a great steak. We finished off with that had to have been the best part of the entire tour - a little ice cream store that served the best gelato I have ever tried. All in all this experience was fantastic. David was a great tour guide - chatty, funny, and full of wisdom about wine and food. He gave us a great list of places to check out while we were in town. It was the perfect way to kick off our Buenos Aires trip. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone looking to try some great food that you would be sure to miss otherwise. Great experience, wonderful food, and definitely a worthwhile tour!

Great Food Tour. David was an excellent tour guide, very informative regarding food and wine and gave us great tips for the rest of our trip regarding which cocktail bars/restaurants we should try and tourist attractions we should see before we leave.The restaurants itself were really good and the food was great, the gelato at the end was uh-mazing. I would highly reccommend everyone choosing David's site to try the food tour, the Palermo food tour was very tasty and definately a high light of the trip for us.

Great eating!. Even having lived in Buenos Aires for a couple of years, they managed to surprise me! David and his team really know their way around as well as any local and have chosen some excellent spots - both the bife and the ice-cream we had on the Cáñitas tour are up with the best I have ever had in this city.It is, of course, pricier than going it alone, but this is a great way for visitors on short trips to get some initial bearings in BsAs - particularly if you don't speak Spanish.
Best part of my trip.. This tour was excellent. The hosts were very friendly and helpful. The food was excellent. I really felt like I was doing something special.

Palermo Tour. The places we visited on the food tour were carefully chosen; they were all authentic and one a sort of a no-name secret parilla was particularly interesting to visit. We visited the restaurants in a sequence corresponding to the courses of an Argentine meal. David was very informative, not only about the food, place but also about the local vicinage. David took wonderful care of us, a group of 10 persons, 6 adults and 4 kids, especially dealing patiently with impatient kids. David was also extremely responsive to a number of questions we had during online booking and during the actual tour.He also wrote down a wide variety excellent recommendations for food places for us. I particularly like a wine bar he had suggested.I would perhaps suggest an alternative to the empanada place, we had had better empanadas on the trip.All said, I would whole-heartedly recommend this trip to anybody visiting BA.

Stay away - a rip-off!. I was very much looking forward to this tour but it turned out to be the worst activity we've done in Buenos Aires! Firstly it's extremely overpriced: we paid 130 USD for 2 people which seemed reasonable when we booked it from home (London) but when we got to know the local prices, we realised how much we got ripped off! (see price comparison at the end of the review)Secondly, our guide wasn't chatty, didn't have interesting stories to share etc. She was nice but that's not enough! We met some amazing tour guides during our South American trip and she was definitely not one of them...Thirdly, the description is very misleading: it says you will go to 3 "authentic local restaurants", when in reality you go to 2 restaurants (both outside of 'rush hour' so you're alone in the restaurant therefore it's really not an authentic experience) and then you have some empanada on the street in front of a pizzeria. The only positive was the secret restaurant in Palermo which seemed as it was closed just to keep it's "speakeasy" appeal. If you want a true, 'off the beaten track' food experience in Buenos Aires, go to Paladar, a "puerta cerrada"(secret restaurant)! We had a 5 course gourmet Argentinian menu there with amazing local wines for 30 USD/person. And it's not just the food, but the hosts: Pablo, the chef and Ivana, his wife, the sommelier! Five star experience, highly recommend!

Leave your diet at home!. When you come to Buenos Aires you are in for a treat with the quality of local restaurants. My sister and I did this tour after being in BA for 4 days. The quality and variety of food was superb. The Palermo district is just beautiful. Sabrina our guide was brilliant. She made us feel welcome from the outset and gave us a background to all the culinary delights. My favourite part was when we went to the restaurant that is not opened to the general public. We also consumed some of Argentina's fine red wine The tour finishes with ice cream which I absolutely did not need! But was glad I tried because it was up there with the best I have tasted.Ticks all the boxes and great value for money!

A must to get off the beaten path. As an avid traveller who loves to find the restaurants and bars the locals call home, I was very imprerssed with Parilla Tours on my recent trip to Buenos Aires. Thank you, David, for choosing places not in the tourist guide books and for providing a list of your other local favourites. All 4 stops on the tour were fantastic and we were full for the rest of the day!

Living La Vida Local. I loved the Palermo "lunch" tour. Our guide Sol was great, informative and made us feel like we we were dining with friends. As a solo traveler, It was a great way to experience a non touristy attraction... The places visited, the history behind the foods and of course the great quantity of food was well worth the money A great off the beaten path delight!

A Tasty Tour. David was an excellent tour guide to sample the local cuisine! There was more than enough food and incredible value for money. The grilled cheese / provoleta was amazing!!! Thank goodness we had to walk between restaurants the burn off some of the good eats :-)

Dining out the Porteno way. If you want to experience Argentinian food and dining out the way the locals do, take Parilla Tours Buenos Aires. On the Palermo tour at noon we not only savoured delicious food in places, we would not have found on our own - especially in a secret hidden dive only frequented by local people, who are friends with the owner - our guide also made it a very personal experience, like dining out with friends or family.

Truly authentic tour. My husband and I did the Palermo dinner tour at the end of March. Both David and Sol were so welcoming and we also enjoyed chatting with the other folks on the tour. We started off with choripan which my husband really loved along with some wine. We then walked and had made to order empanadas. We were able to try different varieties other than your standard beef empanada. We then made our way to a local parrilla, of which there is no sign. You wouldn't even know by looking at the front that there is a restaurant. We had a lovely time enjoying the different steaks along with wine. Then we ended at an ice cream shop and enjoyed the local flavors.What made this tour wonderful are the special touches that David and Sol provided throughout the tour. We received some dining tips/guides to eating out and they also pointed out several points of interest throughout our walking tour. We never felt rushed and they really answered all our questions. They even gave us some tips/advice as we were leaving the next day for Mendoza. At the end, my husband and I decided to hang out at a local pub that David pointed out during the walk. Any new visitor to Buenos Aires will find this tour very worthwhile for the local and authentic experience!

Wowwww - A tour in my hometown!!. I went back to Buenos Aires for a few months and I wanted to see what Parrilla tour was like. During the tour, I felt proud of being part of the asado and parrilla traditions and it was great to see how everyone absolutely loved it. Parrilla Tour takes its guest through a journey of traditional food in traditional places and you get to share it with people from all over the world! You don't see only one but four different excellent "porteño" restaurants that you will not find on your own or even reading all your travel guides! I highly recommend it as a true genuine experience you shouldn't miss out even if you only spend a couple of days in the capital of Argentina. David, my host during the tour, showed his love, passion and knowledge for his adoptive hometown - Buenos Aires! GRACIAS!!

The Hole in the Wall Dinner Tour. We did the Parrilla dinner tour in Palermo in mid March - and we highly recommend it. We visited some great eating establishments - that we would never have found on our own. The food and wine were great (and there was lots of both!) and David and Santiago were great hosts. It was like having dinner with friends. If you can arrange it, do the tour your first or second night in BA as David and Santiago can give you lots of tips on what to do in the city!

Great tour!. This food tour was awesome - one of the best things I did on my entire trip to South America! The food was delicious, and the guide was very personable, informative, and helpful. Highly recommended!

The real food tour of Buenos Aires. My husband and I really enjoyed the Parrilla tour in San Telmo. In addition to enjoying the authentic foods of Argentina, a side visit to the mercado was fun! David was an excellent guide and provided Insights into the people of Buenos Aires and the food that was presented. Great way to spend an afternoon in the city!

Local food secrets. I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch time tour in San Telmo. David was an informative and entertaining host. We sampled empanadas, choripan, parrilla and icecream at little owner operated establishments that I would not have thought to enter on my own. I wish I had done this tour earlier in my BA stay. It made me braver about where to eat.

Very Fun Tour - not to miss. David and Santi were fantastic hosts. If you like hidden gems and aren't typically going to venture outside the beaten path on your own, this tour is for you. It was fun starting at a hole in the wall restaurant having chiripan and vino. Meeting everyone in the group and learning a little about the area, food and history. We then went off to have empanadas (for which we ate every day) and these were just about the best. They were only take away, so we ate them on the corner which was fun. You then head to a hidden parrila - gate says closed and looks like a deserted building, but behold a bustling place inside. I was daring and had the blood sausage and it was quite good. The melted cheese was fantastic. Have to say the steak wasn't the best we had on our trip, but was good overall. The final stop was ice cream which was really yummy. We didn't have any other ice cream while there so couldn't say it was the best, but it was very, very good. Overall this is a great trip but have to confess I believe it is a little over priced for those that would typically venture out on your own. However, if you would rather have someone give you a guided tour of a great area, great food, etc. it is just right. You will love hanging out with David and Santi - great guys.

Local Food tour. This tour, led in English by an expat with years of experience living in Buenos Aires, will fill your stomach and mind with interesting local delicacies and culture. There is no better way to be introduced to parilla and empanada joints than to hang with David for a couple of hours on this tour. AND you'll finish off smiling while consuming local ice cream (gelato) !

Truly an insider foodie tour!. Fantastic experience! Started out at an unassuming restaurant and had choripan sandwiches. Then off to a corner place for some fantastic empanadas. Next was the main corse at a secret parrilla where we had food and wine while David and his Argentine assistant (can't remember her name) talked to us about all things food, wine, Argentina, restaurants, culture and language. It was like hanging out with friends who are also very knowledgable about Buenos Aires. Only thing I regret is that we did this near the end of our time in BA. I wish we would have gone on our first or second day so that we can try all the restaurants they recommend and talked about. Last stop was for ice cream and even though we were all full, we still ate it! :) And, thanks to our guides, they mentioned that there was a Polo match happening that day at the nearby polo fields. So we strolled over there (to walk off the food!) and caught a Polo match after the tour. Altogether a wonderful day. Well worth the money for the experience. I highly recommend.

Amazing people and food!. A visit to any city should include a culinary food tour like this. I participated in the Palermo food tour. The guides were great and very knowledgeable. The four restaurants we hit had awesome food. Including choripan, empanadas, steak, wine and dessert. Couldn't have asked for a better way to spend a few hours in Buenos Aires.

Ultimate insider food adventure.. We are great lovers of the grill and its tasty products. Argentine meats--especialy its fully grassfed beef that never sees filthy finishing lots, never needs antibiotics and is usually harvest at much smaller size than their US counterparts--are legendary. Our Parrilla Tour Buenos Aires outing offered meat for sure. but a lot more. The Argentine wood- and charcoal-cooking apparatus is the asado. That is the name for the device and the superb food that can be made on it. An asado is not the same as an American grill or and Aussie Barby. First of all the fat is collected by an angle iron cooking surface so it does not drip into the flames . The Vs in the cook surface channel fat and grease away the embers, not into them like our grills in the USA. So any smokey flavors are minimal at best and arise from the vacinity of the embers and the food, not flaming fat and smoke. The flavor of the asado meal is imparted by the cook, by carefully moving embers around the base of the cooker and also by moving the food away from or closer to those embers. The result is a slowly cooked massterpiece. Santiago, our guide, taught me--master American griller and BBQer at least in my own mind--about this while sitting in front of Oswaldo's metal and brick asado. Oswaldo's been cooking in St. Telmo for decades and grew up right across the street. He has been making choripan--wonderful pork sauage from a "secret source" served with a very lightly warmed bagguete and of course chimichurrie. This Argentine condiment is a gift to griled meats--especially beef. Oswaldo is the "real deal" and a man the locals patronize. Meeting him and eating his food was the highlight of this tour. Santiago is proud of the tradtional cooks he bring shis customers to meet'.including two eighty-plus abuelas, one makes the best empnadas I have ever tasted (ground beef, cumin hardboiled eggs, etc) and the other original and numberous fresh ice creams. We had pistachio, chololate, blueberry and of course dulce de lechie--marvelous flavors and gelato-like mouth feel. (The means a lot since we know great ice cream right here in Columbus.)Another stop on this fine tour confined to just a several block radius, was of course a parrilla. You will learn quickly in Argentina that the double ll is pronounced "sh". I did not see any other tourists while we had lunch at the parrilla Santiago had chosen,and we there at a busy time. SIrloin steaks and flank steak, both cooked on the asado, along with a simple but tasty salad of arugula and cheese; we also had provolonetta (grilled provolone cheese with oregano, chili and olive oil, and once again chimichurie). This was washed down with a Malbec roble.Santiago is well;known in this neck of the woods. He is intersting not just because of his love of food and his knowldege about the foodways of his country (he has been cooking asado since he has a child) but also because of his other interests such as leather design and furniture making. He is so good at what he doesin San Telmo, I doubt he will get much chance to do those other things for know. This tour was well worth the cost--all food is included.

Fun, relaxed and yummy. Great overview of traditional Buenos Aires' eats. I did the evening tour and we hit a secret parrilla, which was a kick. David and Santi were fun, organized and helpful. Check out the blog on their website for tips of other stuff to do in the area as well.

So very worth it!!. We came to Argentina for steak and wine. With so many restaurants in Buenos Aires and so little time we wanted to taste of the best! We signed up for the private tour and it was exactly what we hoped for. We met David and Santiago in the first restaurant and they were waiting with a bottle of wine and fantastic conversation. We went to four places in all, one so hidden and exclusive to locals that we not only would never have found it but if we had, we wouldn't have gotten in! We had the chance to experience meat prepared so lovingly that the taste was pure joy and yet another perfect bottle of wine. There are not enough positive adjectives to describe how lovely David and Santiago are and how special the places they took us were. Afterwards they walked us to a bar and got us a table before taking off. We don't speak much Spanish and some spots cater to the regulars, this tour gave us access and we reaped the benefits!

Food, Fun and facts in BA. David did a fantastic job guiding and explaining the culinary scene of Buenos Aires. We started at a local restaurant with a a classic appetizer and then onto a local empanada place. The highlight was the entree of several cuts of parrilla cooked beef. We finished with helado at a local store. The food was great and the local knowledge made it even better. I would reccomend it early in your trip to help you better understand the cuisine of this great city.

A MUST !. My fiance and I enjoy self directed vacations our trips so far have taken us through , ASIA , Caribbean , Central America , Europe & North America . Our arrival in Buenos Aires a city of 12 or more million can make even the most well travelled person feel "lost" . This was our first experience in South America and we only had a few days in this amazing city before moving elseware . I literally stumpled upon Parrilla Tours actually while looking on line for info on the ferry to Montevideo ... My split second decision to book has been what Steve and I look back on as one of the best highlights of our entire vacation. We went on the San Telmo area tour I would suggest the other ones are just as great. We left full of some of the best food available in the entire city , we gained valuable knowledge on food , culture , wine ...ohhh yes, David is well versed in his wine knowledge, an unexpected bonus ! We had a small intimate group and the atmosphere felt like a group of old friends going out for a social lunch even if we had just met . David made everyone feel comfortable with his professionalism and laid back attitude . I didn't have any expectations to start with and was rewarded with a fantastic experience !

Fantastic way to experience Argentina & Buenos Aires. Was traveling with my Fiance to Buenos Aires for 2 weeks, and this was one of the highlights of the trip. David was a fantastic guide. We did the Palermo version of the tour, and all the places were great and off the map. They walk you through the types of food that are big in Argentina and give a bit of history as well. Would recommend at the beginning of your trip because the information is a great way to set you up for the rest of your time in the city. Couldn't recommend it enough!

Wonderful Parrilla Tour. I was traveling on my own in Buenos Aires and do not particularly like to eat alone, so I chose this tour as one of my side trips, hoping it wouldn't turn out to be some commercial thing with a table full of many nationalities and languages. It turned out to be one of the most delightful afternoons I spent in BA. I joined a couple from Florida, along with David, our guide. The company was wonderful, the food wonderful, and I can't recommend it highly enough. David had every detail planned for. As a starter we ate in one of the oldest buildings in San Telmo, where the cafe was located, and were served by a woman of 82 years, who had the empandas in the open oven baking when we arrive. Delicioso! The entire tour was a combination of culture, food, geography . It did not seem like a "tour." Was more like dining with several friends. Gracias!!!!

Special Afternoon. Our afternoon spend with Parrilla Tours is one of the strongestmemories we have from our recent trip through Argentina. What made itso great was that they had selected incredibly local restaurants, hadobviously taken the time to form great relationships with the ownersand staff, and had structured the entire tour so it was relaxing yethighly informative. Also, since it is a food tour I must comment onthe great food and wine they served us. We loved that we got to trystreet foods at a couple of the stops, the best steak of our wholetrip at the main stop, and wonderfully creamy and fresh gelato tofinish up.

Recommended for Day 1. We hit the ground running and did this tour the same day we arrived in Buenos Aires. We thought it was a nice choice to start with for a couple reasons:Firstly, we learned a lot about cuisine of Argentina, how to order properly, how to get around the city, restaurant recommendations and insider tips. We felt that without this tour we would have wasted a lot of time at mediocre restaurants and not getting an authentic Portena experience. Our guide went far beyond just guiding on the tour, and even made several restaurant reservations, got us half off on our ferry to Uruguay and arranged for a wonderful private driver to take us to Tigre the following afternoon. Secondly, even though we were a bit tired from our travel, the tour was relaxing and what better way to ease yourself into a culture than through delicious food and wine! The group size was only 6, so it was very intimate and did not feel like a touristic activity in the least.

Highly Recommended!. You can learn a lot about a culture or community from the food its people eat and places they gather to do so. You can also have a great time yourself while you learn, partake, and join in the community. But...this can be challenging to figure out on your own, especially in big cities. Hunting on line can certainly help, but often the biggest or most "famous" places can be filled with more tourists than locals. David and Sol from Parrilla Tour to the rescue! What a fantastic experience, provided by two informative and very nice people. They introduced us to the real deal - small places you might walk right past and never know what you were missing - and a history or story to go along with it. Great food and great company. Highly recommended!!

Authentic Restaurant Tour. The Parrilla Tour was a highlight of our trip to Buenos Aires. Justas they advertise of their website, the focus of the tour is authenticlocal restaurants that you would likely never find as a tourist. Allof the stops had incredible food and character, definitely no otherforeigners in sight. Our guide, a young woman from Buenos Airesanswered our endless questions and assisted us in planning the rest ofour stay in the city.

a great way to enjoy typical BA food. On our third trip to Buenos Aires we decided to try the Parilla Tour, mostly because we believe that parilla (charcoal) is the most terrific way to cook - it is nothing like a typical barbecue. As we discovered, the secret is not to have red hot charcoal, but to keep the fire cool enough to be able to grill cheese. We had a terrific time with our lovely guide David (half American, half Argentine) on our magical mystery tour around a part of Palermo we didn't know. He was more than happy to share his wealth of knowledge about the local food, culture, localities etc. We tried empanadas, and chimichurri, and parilla and delicious Malbec wine - not to mention wonderful ice-cream and coffee to finish. I can really recommend it!!

A Fantastic Cultural Food Tour Experience. My husband booked a luncheon tour for our first full day in Buenos Aires prior to boarding our cruise ship. What a delightful experience. Our guide, David, was an ex-pat from Portland, Oregon and extremely knowledgeable about wines and those hidden little neighborhood restaurants that you would never find on your own. We enjoyed a real taste of the BA culture and the food that native residents enjoy. David was a wonderful guide to not only the food but the culture of this amazing city. If you are looking for more than the usual type of tours, take a tour with Parrilla.

Take this tour!. We chose the private tour because we really wanted to be able to experience 'far off the beaten path' BA food and we had an amazing time! It was my partner and I and two guides, David and Santi who were gracious and welcoming, full of knowledge about BA and Argentinian food, and really excited about sharing some of their favorite eateries. We had a great meal full of Argentinian specialties and saw some locations that are truly unknown to the guidebooks and concierges of the world. I would hands down encourage you to take this tour! We came away with full bellies and a lot of great food, wine, and restaurant recommendations.

Great lunch activity in BA. Delicious way to discover off the path, fun lunchtime fare. David is a terrific host, full of information about BA and greater Argentina. Try to go on one of your first days in BA.

One of the best things of our trip to Buenos Aires. Santiago and David are charming introductions to the best of Buenos Aires. They are relaxed and full of interesting information about B.A. The food tour is wonderful and delicious and shouldn't be missed - they know their stuff. Also I can't say enough about how helpful they are. We had a very unfortunate start to our trip (cab driver ripping us off and hotel booked a dive). They took it upon themselves to find us a charming hotel, get their car, drive us clear across the city, get our bags and take us to the other end again to the new hotel. Can't thank them enough!Book this tour - it's something that shouldn't be missed.

Don`t miss this....!!. A fantastic experience. If you`re a traveller who really wants to experience something different and totally authentic this walking tour is for you. Santiago is a charming, educated and well-informed guide who lives in Buenos Aires and makes the evening a memorable experience. Visiting a totally authentic restaurant with no tourists in sight I tasted the best steak I have ever had followed by ice cream I had only imagined! After that we went to a tango hall visited only by locals. All the venues are tucked away and you`d never find them on your own. The restaurant had `closed` on the door and you have to go down a passage to get to it. Its name is changed every 6 weeks to keep it like a private dining room for local people! Ideal for very small groups, couples or solo travellers.

Sebastian and Sabrina know how to lead a tour!. Once again Sandra of www.batravelguide.com booked our group of six into a terrific tour. We met up with Sebastian and Sabrina in Palermo and had a full afternoon of good eats, great conversation and new best friends. Chorizo, empanadas, provolone with oregano, ensalada mixta, sirloin and skirt steak, Malbec of course and finishing up with ice cream. We walked, we talked, we enjoyed. Fabulous!! What a way to learn what a true parrilla have to offer.

Great food and great guide. I choose this tour because it sounded authentic, not touristy, and I thought it may give my 4 travel companions, on their first trip to South America, some nice memories. Well, let me tell you that it was a total success. We arrived a bit early at the meeting point, but no worries, David was already there (it shows professionalism and respect for his clients), that already impressed me. The tour takes you to local, real food places so you can taste what the majority of portenos eat on a regular day. Everything was great, the choripan, the empanadas, the meat, my friends still can't believe the amount of meat they ate and how good it was. I think they will remember the Parilla Tour forever. David was very helpful in answering all kind of questions and giving tips for things to see or other places to eat, he even contacted a friend who contacted another friend in order to give my colleague some addresses of places where she could find some "tango" shoes. Good food, incredible good meats, as much wine as you want, a bit of history of the neighborhood and B.A., and great ice cream to end...you can't ask for anything better.

Great evening discovering fantastic local food.. Our group of 6 enjoyed a lovely evening with David, discovering 3 local restaurants in an area of BA that we hadn't visited previously. Both the food and wine were fantastic, and David had very good knowledge of the food and the city. He also recommended (and made a booking for us) a restaurant for dinner the following night which was a highlight of our trip.

Meat, meat, marvellous meat. I was a solo traveller in Buenos Aires in December 2013 and was a little hesitant to go wandering the streets late at night to find the best places to eat and drink. I saw a segment on Australian TV show, Getaway, about the Tour and it intrigued me so I booked. I was really happy with the way the tour was run and the food and wine I got to experience. David really knows his way around Buenos Aires and the local connections he has made with restaurateurs is very impressive. I would recommend this tour to couples, singles or foodies in general who are keen to try traditional food and meet new people.

Great guides and great food!. Our group of 10 took the Palermo food tour with David and Santiago and came away very impressed with their local knowledge and very full from 4 great local food spots. Our tour included Choripan, Empanadas, a steak fest, gelato and wine. The spots that David and Santiago selected were definitely local spots off of the beaten path and places that we never would have found even with research. In fact the parilla (steakhouse) that we visited was a Secret local Parilla which was located in a nondescript gated building with absolutely no signage whatsoever. The food was amazing as were David and Santiago. I would highly recommend this tour for anyone traveling to BA!

Go! Go! Go!. I just went on the San Telmo tour yesterday and it was awesome. David our guide has a great knowledge of the food and wine that we consumed. I ate the best empanada I´ve ever had....anywhere. The food was so good that I´m going to repeat the tour on my own tomorrow......seriously. Book this tour. You´ll love it.

Great intro to BA food. We took this tour as our very first activity upon arrival to BA, and it was a great decision. David and Santiago brought us to several great places, one of which we would have NEVER gone to because it's a "closed door" restaurant and impossible to find unless you know it's there. Delicious food! Even better, they had a lot of advice and recommendations for our stay in Argentina. Highly recommend!

Hidden gems, great food!. We had a lovely lunchtime experience at several neighborhood restaurants that we would never have found on our own. David and Santiago are gracious hosts and know the cuisine. Delicious choripan and empanadas to start. Great steaks and wine at a 'secret' parilla, followed by the famous BA ice cream at a local shop. Enjoyable from beginning to end!
Delicious food!. David was super helpful, took us to wonderful places to eat that we would not have found on our own, and shared with us very interesting information on food and culture in Argentina.

Eating our way across Argentina. The "parrilla tour" was a great way to start our tour of Argentina. We started by meeting at a parrilla on Baez St around noon, had a briefing & met the other participants. A local was sitting behind me eating a steak; the steak was twice as big as any steak I have ever had in a restaurant. IMPRESSIVE beginning. Here we had a chorizo sausage "hot dog style" with 2 different sauces.Then we walked a block or so to a' take out empanada shop". We stood on the sidewalk and had the best empanada I have ever.Then we walked to the "secret parrilla" where we had a nice salad, one of those grilled cheese disk things (OPA.....), and a big, great piece of steak, wine, another big platter of steak, more wine. My wife doesn't eat red meat and had a platter of fish for a family of 4. WOW.Finally a walk to a gelato shop.T can't understand how Argentinians can eat like this and look as slim as they do. We had 2 similar steak based "lunches" touring wineries in Mendoza.Argentina has the best tastiest tenderist steaks I have ever eaten, and that includes Ruth's Chris in New Orleans on Veteran's Blvd.

Great Hospitality. Was part of the parrilla tour recently, through the oldest area in Buenos Aires. The food and wine was great, especially the wine, make sure you go hungry. The tour guides Santiago and David are friendly and very helpful.

Mucho delicioso!. Brilliant idea, well executed. There were just four on our tour (from US, UK and us from Canada) plus Santiago, the guide. Food was all good, but the best part is that you're eating in places that are you'd never find by yourself. The evening ended much too soon!PS-not recommended for vegetarians :)

Best way to spend first day in Buenos Aires. We arrived in BA on an early morning flight, and wanted something uncomplicated to do on the first day. We found the Parrilla tour online before we left and are so glad we made this our first experience in BA.David and Santiago took us to out of the way places that we would never have found by our selves. The food was fantastic and the company just as good. The food was better than we had at one of the "fancy/upscale" parrillas, and it was a great value.I highly recommend this tour to any foodie, or anyone who wants a great introduction to Buenos Aires

Authentic flavors of Buenos Aires. We tried 4 different big name parrillas independently while in Buenos Aires, and walked away from them all feeling like we were missing something. The food was good, but not as incredible as we thought beef would be in Argentina. We discovered this food tour on Trip Advisor and decided to give Argentine steak one more chance. We were not disappointed. The food was outstanding, the restaurants the guide chose to take us to were small and filled with locals, and the guides went above and beyond to make sure we had everything we needed and that our entire trip, even after the tour, was a special food experience.

Great introduction to Buenos Aires. This tour is run by two very cool, casual, fun guys -- one local, and one US transplant. The tour is really comprehensive, you try everything from choripan and empanadas, to awesome steaks in an off-the-beaten-track Parilla. This is a great tour to do right when you touch down--schedule it for your first or second day, because you'll get all kinds of tips to enhance the rest of your stay.

Amazing experience!. We did the Parilla tour during our first afternoon in Buenos Aires and we were definitely satisfied about the places we visited and the amazing argentinian food we tried. For sure you we recommend doing this tour during your first days in Argentina because the guides are really knowledeable about the authentic places to visit during your stay in Buenos Aires.

Excellent food tour. We met santiago and Sabrina, our tour guides, in Palermo on a rainy afternoon. They were both friendly, gracious and accommodating. I eat no red meat and my husband loves it. We were both very full and happy at the end of the tour. We had a larger group, but it was never a problem and was more like a party! Santiago and Sabrina also offered great insider tips for other attractions in the city and answered any questions we had, including directions. I highly recommend the parilla tour in Palermo!

Best Food Tour I've Ever Done. Really enjoyable! Places we stopped were excellent, and it's a great way to sit and down and meet some other travelers. I was traveling by myself, so this was really nice.What really set this tour apart from other food tours I've done is that you get MORE than enough food. Others have always been little bites, but this is a full on meal, including dessert!A must do!

Snapshot of San Temlo. We booked this tour at the beginning of our visit to Buenos Aires to get a flavour of traditional food in the most traditional neighbourhood in Buenos Aires, and it absolutely hit the mark. David and Santiago are friendly guys, fluent in English and Spanish, and host you around San Temlo like friends. Starting at a famous old panaderia for empanadas, we moved on for a quick tour of the iconic San Temlo markets with a visit to a "hole in the wall" grill for chori-pan ( you would never think to stop there, to your loss - we went back on our own ! ). Main meal at a truly old school parrilla, one of the oldest in San Temlo with stories to tell. Final stop at artesanal ice cream cafe, Buenos Aires is THE place for icecream lovers ! I particularly recommend this tour if you have limited time in Buenos Aires as it condenses some of the key culinary experiences to have into a few hours, and provides a great snapshot of the true San Temlo.
Parrilla tour. Probly the best thing i done in argentina. Great experience and the tour guides are awesome. Highly recommend it.

An experience to not miss!. If your unsure to book an amazing food experience with this small company then think no more. first setting off to dine at the finest empanada restaurant then to dinner where you will taste the finest cheeses, meats and wine and finely washing it all down with the BEST ice team (dulce de leche). both David and Santiago are amazing and will go to any extent to ensure you enjoy your night!!! thanks guys!

Fun activity in BA!. Super fun activity in BA - we did the Palermo tour and tasted many characteristic foods of Argentina. I would suggest doing this at the beginning of your trip - so you know what to order for the rest of your stay!

Best tour of our trip!. We loved the Parrilla Tour with David and Santigo. The explanation of the history and culture of the food and the city was very informative and interesting. You feel like a local out with a group of friends, not a tourist. I recommend this tour to anyone visiting BA. It was one of the best parts of our trip!

Incredible local food lunch tour!. Our delightful tour with David in Palmerno provided a wonderful opportunity to experience delicious local food prepared in places where Porteños eat. We made four stops in a very walkable neighbourhood, with the best of classic Argentine foods. We highly recommend doing this early during your Buenos Aires visit. You will learn so much about the food that you will confidently order your next meal.

Relaxed lunch with friends, not a tour!. Our second time in Buenos Aires and joining again the Parilla Tour but in a different neighborhood/route.We did this tour on saturday with David and Santiago and felt compelled to write a review because we had such a worderful time again. Last time my wife posted one. Now I want to explain my reasons of booking this activity again. 1) it was very social 2) the food and wine was all top quality and they were happy to offer more of everything or even order another cut that one of the guests requested 3) a great value, 69 usd. 4) great organization sharing insider knowledge. The chance to visit the secret spots made it easily worth the price.

A delightful experience in every way. We had a delightful experience on this tour. Our host, Santiago was both charming and knowledgeable. He clearly takes great pride in showing the best of his neighbourhoodand we were very happy to see a slice of Buenos Aires through a local's eyes. The food was excellent, particularly the empanadas --- the best I have tasted by far. Our group was small enough to have real conversations, and Santiago was happy to explain and answer any questions we had. An additional treat was his recommendation for a local tango club. We visited it after the tour, and it was just as I had hoped ---- a real neighbourhood experience. I will certainly recommend this to my friends as they head to BA. In fact, the next time I go, I think I will take the San Telmo tour, just for the fun of it!

Go for the food, wine and guides. Back in December I went on the parrilla tour. Luckily I went on the day I arrived in BsAs since our guide, a young woman from Buenos Aires, explained so much about the culture of Argentina, and the best spots to visit in Buenos Aires. Everything from museums, milongas, shopping, restaurants, to bars. The recommendation for the flower shop cocktail bar was amazing! The chat about parrilla culture and how to order meat was very helpful in the following days since it would have been very overwhelming not knowing anything.

Great way to see the city like a local. I took the tour with good friends on the first day in Buenos Aires. We took the Palermo tour, and David and Santiago were great hosts. They explained everything thoroughly, and you could tell they really loved what they did. They answered any questions we threw their way and really made us feel at home. It was also great to get to know the other guests - we had a British couple and a few different American families on our particular tour. We started out with choripan (which I loaded up with the spicy pepper sauce - so good!). Then it was off to the empanada spot, which was stuffed with beef. After, we sat down to a delicious steak lunch at one of the closed door spots that won't let you in unless they know you're coming. We started out with proveleta - a grilled provolone topped with spices. Cheese lovers will not be disappointed. Next, it was on to all the meats! There was the matambre (thin pork you squeeze lemon on), a prime rib-like cut, and a skirt steak (my personal favorite). We washed it down with some Malbec, which was delicious. Last, we had ice cream (dulce de leche of course). Needless to say, you should go hungry! It would be a great idea if you're coming on one of the flights that land super early in BsAs and you want to do something lowkey but still see the city on your first day. Eating like a local is delicious job, and someone's gotta do it.

Second time doing Parrilla Tour. On my most recent visit to BsAs, I went back to Parrilla Tour for the second time. I did the tour back in 2012 and loved it then - but it's even better now! I did the Palermo tour which took us to the Secret Parrilla - one of the best parrillas I have been to in BsAs. Santi and David really know their history and love to share their love of Argentine culture with a fun group of travelers. This is a must do for anyone visiting BsAs. It's good for first time visitors and for those who think they already know the food scene - you will be pleasantly surprised!

Worth Going Twice. On a trip to Argentina over the Christmas / New Years Holiday our group of four got to do the Parrilla Tour in San Telmo section of Buenos Aires. The tour was so good we were fortunate to be able to make a reservation for the Palermo tour on the day of our departure.The first tour was led by Santiago. He is very enthusiastic about the food and culture of Argentina and he shares his passion with the group. This helped to make a group of strangers relaxed and very friendly, sharing trip tips and travel ideas.Santi took us to four great spots to sample Empanadas, then Choripan, a marvelous Parilla lunch with great steak, salad, Malbec and champagne .The it was on for homemade ice cream .On the second tour we got to go to the Secret Parilla This time we got Provoleto, various cuts of steak ,grilled pork called Mathambre, Malbec more champagne and great company. Without Santi and David we could never get in to this phenomenal restaurant. Entry is reserved for locals and people known to the owner. It would be a shame t come to Buenos Aires and miss this place. This alone was worth the tour. We learned new things and tasted different styles of the local fare. Again the group was friendly and engaging, certainly due to the atmosphere the tour leaders create.Next time in Bs As we will do the tour again!!

Good food, people watching and value. This is a nice way to better understand the dining scene in Buenos Aires. The meat in general is very high quality in Argentina, but this tour takes you to hole in the wall restaurants not frequented by tourists, where you get to see and taste the real Buenos Aires. Well run and a good value for what you get.

A great way to start a trip through Argentina - excellent people. An absolute must!!. During our honeymoon in Argentina we took the Parilla Tour with Santiago. We did the tour on our 2nd day, and are so glad we did it early on. Santiago explained all the details of parilla culture, the food and wine of Argentina, and helped us plan our dining in Buenos Aires to maximize our stay. The highlight though were the spots he took us to. Here's a quick run-through of them:1) We met at an awesome little corner parrilla for choripan, their version of a hot dog, but way better. It was homemade and paired with my now favorite condiment, chimichurri!2) After walking 3-4 blocks we ate a fresh hot out of the oven steak empanada. This placed used chopped steak, not ground beef like we had at other spots. 3) Obviously Argentina is famous for steak and the main stop did not disappoint. It was a parilla steakhouse. It was so local and authentic. The entire staff greeted us with hugs and kisses upon entering! The steak was outstanding. Very flavorful and tender. All this was paired with the best wine we tasted in Argentina. The food and wine kept coming! 4) The finale was ice cream at a little ice cream shop. A little more modern than the other stops, but probably the best ice cream either of us had ever eaten. You could see them making the ice cream fresh. Overall a great way to start a trip through Argentina. Well worth the time and cost.

Just what we needed!!. We did this tour on our 3rd day in Buenos Aires. The city is huge and chaotic at times, so after a couple days we were a bit exhausted. The Parrilla Tour was exactly what we needed, a nicely paced and not at all rushed afternoon of good food, wine and company. Our guides told us interesting stories about the foods we tried, the restaurants and even the neighborhood. The price was more than the average price of our other meals in Buenos Aires, but the insider access and unique experience made it well worth the cost.Gracias & thank you!

Best food we had in Buenos Aires. The food on this tour was a highlight of our stay in Buenos Aires. Everything from the artisanal chorizo to perfectly cooked steak to the best ice cream we´ve ever had. The guides were very friendly and helpful in making sure we had enough of everything, and with answering our questions about how the dishes were prepared and the dining culture of Argentina. Very good tour!

Authentic walking tour w/ delicious bites and informative local insights. If you're looking for an authentic walking tour within the Palermo's Las Canitas area this is the tour for you. It's lead by David, one of the Co Founders of Parrilla Tour Beunos Aires who is great. He's very well informed of the authentic local cuisines as well as information about the local area. He's an American living and loving Buenos Aires so he has great energy and passion for the city he shares with the guests. The tour starts with a visit to a Classis Carrilla (an authentic local restaurant) where you taste DELICIOUS Choripan (essentially Chorizo on Bread with delicious flavorful sauces). You then you visit an Empanadas Shop, another delicious stop with moist tasty empanadas and for lunch you dine at a "Secret" Parrilla. Be sure to save room for the grand finale, Heladeria ice cream stop. It's delicious tastes almost like Gelato which makes sense since there are a ton of Italian immigrants in Argentina. We were told the ice cream is something brought over from Italy hence the amazing Gelato like taste.I hope you enjoy the tour as much as I did. Thanks again David and Parrilla Tour for the great afternoon of dining, great company and a fun walking tour.

A must for food lovers. I went for the dinner tour at Palermo and thoroughly enjoyed it. Santiago was knowledgeable about the neighbourhood eating haunts and their history. I especially liked the secret parrilla restaurant which catered mainly to the locals living in that area. The atmosphere was very lively and you get a good feel of Portenas/Portenos having dinner. I highly recommend this tour!

Best intro to Argentinian street food. We took the Palermo tour and loved the food. Started with choripan (chorizo con pan, sausage on great) which was delicious. This was warm and both the chorizo and pan were homemade! Yum! Then we walked to place for empanadas. It's a small corner store and we stood in the street, there is on seating. The weather had been so hot that this store lost their electricity and so there were no empanadas there. Our adorable guides said not to worry, they would make sure we had empanadas at our next stop. Sure enough the empanadas were the first course at a secret, sit-down restaurant. This restaurant was air conditioned so we relaxed with empanadas, wine and then the main meal, salad, two kinds of steak. All was good. We left there and went to an ice cream place with so many kinds to choose from it was hard to decide.

San Telmo is the tour to take with Parilla Tours. We signed up for the San Telmo tour prior to leaving for BA. Out tour was on the 23rd of December and it was a very busy one. We joined hungry and excited visitors from the US and Australia. Must say that the meeting place at Pedro Telmo was the most authentic and brilliant choice for the start of the tour. Our guide Santiago was very attentive and knowledgeable. The gramma's home made empanadas were amazing! Loved the oldest barrio of BA with the feeling of having gone back in time. The tour included three food stops plus an ice-cream stop. Must do it, will give you a benchmark for food for the rest of your stay. We enjoyed it so much we repeated it the following day. We have also seen others from "our tour" doing the same. Funny!

A must-try food tour. I emailed David through his Parrilla blog only for the info of Uruguay without reading his blog at all. David was kind to share with me the info of Uruguay and Buenos Aires without selling his food tour to me. I only realized that he has a food tour after I read his blog and I was the one who initiated to ask about his food tour! Of course he was very welcoming for us to join him!I decided to take his tour simply because I believed that he could bring us to the local gems where they would not be easy to find if you are not the local. We took his dinner tour at Palermo. We tried 4 different dishes: Choripan, Empanadas, Secret Parrilla and ice-cream. The highlight for us was the secret Parrilla, you would never get to eat at the "Secret Parrilla" unless you are a local and you must know where they are, they change their name every 3 months! It's really interesting! During the tour, David, Santiago and Mariano were explaining well about all the food and the local culture! They are simply knowledgable! We were very satisfied with the good food. David was very nice as he continued to email me where and what to do in BA even after we had done the food tour! This Parrilla food tour is definitely one of the to-do list if you are on holidays in Buenos Aires!

Good introduction to Argentine cuisine. The hosts did really well and took us through lots of very locals style establishments from having a choripan in a 200 year old corner bar that used to be a dairy farm, to eating a empanada in the street to a very fine Parilla restaurant where everything looked shut but if you know the code they'll let you in. Al very good stuff I have to say. A bide de chorizo some pork matambre and some entrana served with a salad and some spicy chimmichurri sauce, surely one of Argentina's greatest gifts to the world. Recommend.

Local Food Tour. We did their Palermo tour this afternoon and greatly enjoyed it. Besides our group their were no other foreigners at the restaurants we visited. The steak was really great, tender and full of flavor. Amazing that they only used salt to season it. We're going to book their other tour route for later in our trip when we return to Buenos Aires after going to Iguazu Falls - Madison Wells, NYC

Nice Introduction to Argentinian Food. My husband and I did the Parrilla Tour in Palermo one hot afternoon in December. Our guide was really nice, and the sampling of places we visited gave us a nice introduction to Argentinian Food. Our guide also provided us with a nice booklet of restaurants to visit (though we had already gotten similar things from other tours / doing our own research). We had a choripan (sausage on a bun) in one restaurant, then walked to an empanada place for another snack. The empanada was quite good - we thoroughly enjoyed that. We had our actual lunch at a 'secret' parrilla (we won't spoil the secret or the details), but apparently it's out of the radar of BA 'foodies'. While the meal was nice and quaint, and the restaurant owners were quite welcoming, the actual steak was only okay. We had much better steak elsewhere. We ended up at a gelateria for dessert. It was nice, but also, nothing too out of the ordinary. Out of the entire experience, the empanada was the best part. To note, we went to a couple of puerta cerradas prior to this tour, and we felt that relative to what we got in those experiences, this tour was relatively more expensive, and not quite as delicious. All in all, it's a nice introduction to Argentinian food, but in all honesty, we had better experiences elsewhere. The value for us just wasn't there.

Best ever. Visiting here from Oklahoma and this was probably one of my best experiences of my life time.
Tour leaders were absolutely out of this world and one can tell that this is more about their passion than making money.
No joke

a great sampling of the typical Argentinian cuisine. We met David and Santiago in Palermo viejo for our Parrilla tour. They are both friendly, outgoing, very knowledgeable and fun to spend the afternoon with. We started at a parrilla with some delicious choripan, a large local sausage with all the condiments, walked on a few blocks to have the best empanada I've tasted, then on to a "secret" parrilla where you can only get in if you know the owners. There we had a meal of the typical beef, made right in front of us on their open oven, with all the sides, wine and drinks included. There were 5 of us that day from the US, UK, and Australia. I asked for white wine and they graciously complied. It was delicious and a very filling meal. We then went on to a wonderful gelato place with every flavor imaginable ( at least 8 Different Dulce de Leche varieties alone! We wobbled out, totally full and satisfied with the wonderful food,and company . Don't miss this chance to experience true Argentine food and culture presented by 2 of the nicest people.

A wonderful experience - Highly recommended!. I was lucky enough to go on one of Parilla's insider food tours and yesterday and it was fabulous! Our guides were so gracious, resourceful and warm and I cannot thank them enough for sharing their knowledge with us all. The food (empanadas, steak and artisanal ice cream) were all perfectly prepared and a delight to eat. Thank you to our brilliant guides for showing us those four authentic, otherwise untouristed local places and giving us a real taste of the real porteno culinary life. Congratulations and thank you :)

Great Introduction To Classic Argentinian Barbecue!. What great fun. My wife and I just returned to our apartment in Recoleta after spending a delightful early afternoon with Santiago and Sabrina, our tour guides with Parrilla Tours. Ate our way around San Telmo and learned a great deal about classic parrilla. Terrific guides, we met other delightful visitors to this great city and the food rocked. Do yourself a favor and sign up for one of their tours. Fabulous deal!p.s. I am stuffed. Time for a nap :).

Take this tour if you come to Buenos Aires.. This tour is a great experience for those who travel for food. The guides will give you an introduction to the culture and cuisine of Buenos Aires not to mention delicious samples from local restaurants. It's a great opportunity to meet other travelers and learn about the city from guides that love the city and its food culture and want to share it with you.

San Telmo. Really enjoyed our tour. It isn't cheap, but we went to the meeting place only 4 hours after landing in Buenos Aires and really appreciated the tips that the guys gave us, we utilised many of them during our stay (polo, tango etc). The food was excellent and really good way to experience San Telmo. Highly recommend.

Worth Every Penny. Due to the nasty BA traffic, we did not arrive until a half hour after the tour started, but Santi and David were kind enough to leave their phone number and directions to the next restaurant so we could still meet up. I cannot say enough about the quality of food we enjoyed on the trip, and Santi and David's intimate knowledge of the city offered an experienc we could have never acheived on our own. My only regret is that we were unable to do both the Palermo and San Telmo tours. However, through email Santi was kind enough to offer us a recommendation so that we could visit their favorite parilla in San Telmo anyhow. I highly recommend this tour to anyone who wants a true BA parilla experience.

Best Steak!. While in Buenos Aires we ate steak just about every night, and were able to check off all the big name parrillas: La Cabrerra, Don Julio, Cabana La Lila and La Brigada, but none of the steaks we had were as good as the sirloin steak on the parrilla tour. Maybe they weren't as nicely decorated, but the food and authenticity of the parrillas we visited were the best we tried. The two women that led our group were very enthusiastic about food and wine, and made sure everyone had a wonderful afternoon.

Delicious Afternoon in Palermo. We had originally signed up for the tour route in San Telmo, but because our flight to BA was delayed, we didn't arrive in time. Luckily they were nice enough to offer to reschedule us for another day's tour in Palermo. We loved the tour. Our guides took us to restaurants that we would have never found without them. They were all exactly the type of place we love, small, authentic, family run and with the best food in the city. Sharing the table with a few other couples was nice and we ended up going out to dinner the next evening with some of them. Would definitey recommend you do the parrilla tour.

Professional insider access. Santiago was friendly, knowledgeable and very keen to provide any BA advice sought. More importantly, the eateries on his list were all of a particularly high quality - definitely a tour worth taking - your taste buds will thank you !

Food and Culture. We participated in the San Telmo Parrilla Tour earlier in the month. It lasted just under 3 hours and took us to 4 separate restaurants to try foods at each. We really enjoyed that it was very relaxed but also professionally run. The food and wines we tried were wonderful and our guide made sure everyone had plenty. We both though afterwards that it would have been good to do right at the start of our trip instead of the last day since you learn a lot about Argentinian culture, food and customs.

Not to be Missed. I recently took the Parrilla Tour in the neighborhood of Palermo. This was a great introduction into the culinary world of Buenos Aires. David and Santiago were wonderful hosts and were very informative. I was surprised at how much food they gave us! i did not leave hungry as we were treated to a complete 4 course meal (so to speak) including wine. If you want to be "in the know" this is the tour for you. You won't be visiting the usual places you will find in all the guidebooks, they have handpicked some of the best, "local favorite", restaurants. The vibe is less "tour" and more of a walking dinner party. This is a "must" for all visiting Buenos Aires.

San Telmo tour. We did the San Telmo Parilla tour in Nov 2013 and really enjoyed it, the restaurants are all great local places and food was excellent. This was actually the best steak we had while in Argentina! It is a great way to get a feel for the San Telmo neighborhood.

Don't miss Parrilla Tour Buenos Aires. This tour is a must on your visit to Buenos Aires! We so enjoyed the tour, the food, and David and his colleague's obvious knowledge, interest and enthusiasm for the food, wine and culture of Buenos Aires. Our 4 stops were sadly reduced to 3 only because of a heavy rain storm the night of our tour but David did not miss a beat and made sure that we had a wonderful dessert at our third stop on the tour. We also enjoyed meeting the other tourists on our tour - very interesting people that shared with us their tips and things to be sure to do/see on our visit. In our next visit to Buenos Aires we will be sure to add the lunch tour that they offer! We missed it this trip because we had such a packed itinerary but will be sure to make it on our list of things to do next time. Don’t hesitate to add this tour to your trip itinerary. You will be very happy you did.

Innovative tour. This tour deserves an "excellent" rating for its innovation. Our group of 5 were led by two guides and enjoyed each of the stops we made. The "Secret Parrilla" was a real curiosity and a long way of the usual tourist trail. David and his Argentinian born colleague were excellent hosts and open to discussion on most topics. I had imagined that we would have covered a larger distance on foot but on a very hot day we were pleased to keep it down to less than a kilometre. A fun way to see the local culture in Buenos Aires.

Delicious way to see the city!. Wonderful tour! Not only was Dave very informative about the history of the neighborhood, he gave an excellent overview of the different foods that we ate. The more he went into detail about the history of each meat/dish, our interests and appetites were equally accommodated! Would definitely recommend it!

Day 1. Like some others mentioned in their reviews, this is a must do tour for early on in your stay in Buenos Aires. You gain so much information and are given lots of insider tips about restaurants, other tours, shopping, discounts, local culture, what to avoid, and getting around. The tour itself was fantastic and well organized. All of the stops selected had a special local feel, and were not touristic at all. The food was excellent and the portions were more than generous. Our tips, go day 1, and go hungry! Susan and Elliot - Los Angeles, USA

Great Way to Spend an Afternoon in Buenos Aires!. My mom and I went on the tour of San Telmo and had such a great time! David was a wonderful host and gave the group interesting insights about the different foods we tried and the places we stopped at. The food was incredible, especially the empanada at our first stop.In addition to the tour itself, we also got a list of recommendations for eating throughout the city, which was wonderful. David was nice enough to suggest one of the places on the list for us to try the next day, which we did and loved.I would recommend this to anyone visiting Buenos Aires as a great and fun way to get to know the city a little better.

Definitely Book This Awesome Food Tour!. Since my niece had a few days to work in Argentina, I searched for a tour to book for myself. Since it is such a personalized tour, I felt welcomed by our host, David, and was very comfortable even though I was by myself. David was so knowledgeable about the food and wine of Argentina that I would recommend booking this tour early on in your trip so that you can use some of his restaurant recommendations. All of the food was great from the empanadas to the ice cream. After our first stop (where we had tasty empanadas), we walked through an outdoor market in San Telmo where fresh meats, fruits, and other local wares were for sale. At a small food stand, we ate homemade choripan which is a sausage served on outstanding grilled bread. The menu for the day was written on paper, and the owner, a retired accountant, does this as a hobby. David told me that if he doesn't want to open for the day, he doesn't. What a special treat. The local restaurant where we had steak, was the best that I had while in Argentina; much better than the touristy parillas. The flavor of the beef was outstanding and enhanced by the wonderful chimichurri sauce. Their version of grilled cheese wasn't even close to what we have in the United States; it was so creamy and crunchy. The salad was so fresh and, of course, there was a great bottle of wine. The tour ended with dessert at a local ice cream shop. What a way to end such a flavorful experience. The sights, sounds, and smells were intoxicating. David always asked if we had any questions after he shared such great information on the history of food and wine in Argentina. Since I had about 10 blocks to walk to catch the subway back to my hotel, I asked David which direction I should go. He told me of a more scenic route to take than the one I took to get to the food tour. It was great advice as I saw some awesome sights on the way. Also, he was always good about taking my picture in each place we visited.

Excellent food tour of Palermo. We particpated in their tour in Palermo. All of the restaurants we ate at were just our style, super local with great food and people watching. It was very well organized and our tables were waiting for us when we walked in the door at each place. Our guide was invaulable in helping us plan our dining in Buenos Aires as well as Mendoza. Their connections even helped us get a table at a restaurant that had told us they were fully booked for the entire week!

Great Tour in San Telmo!. My husband and I booked this trip after learning about it on TripAdvisor. We booked it for the day we were supposed to arrive in Buenos Aires....sounded like it would be the perfect introduction to the city. Unfortunately, we had some travel complications and ended up missing the tour completely. We were totally bummed about it, but David was kind enough to reach out to us and make sure everything was okay since we didn't show up. Moreover, he actually rescheduled us on another tour for our last day. I just thought it was so kind and accommodating of him to do that. The actual tour totally exceeded our expectations. We went to 3 local Parrillas & ended the afternoon with a delightful stop at an ice cream place. Everything we tasted was delicious. I think my favorite part, however, was just the amount of local information that David and his colleague passed on to us during the tour. We certainly wish we had obtained this information on our first day rather than our last day. I guess we will just need to come back and do it all over again :) Great tour, great guides, would recommend to anyone.

Delicious steak - San Telmo tour. The San Telmo tour was easy to book online and we really enjoyed it! We started at the Parrilla and enjoyed empanadas (see the photo). The chopan (chorizo and bread) at another stop was tasty, especially the house-made chimichurri. At the steakhouse we were treated to as much steak as we could possibly eat. The locals were only eating meat and did not have the small cups of arugula that we were served. The skirt steak was quite a bit more tender that what we are used to in the US. The Argentine steak is grass-fed, so it is surprising that it is as tender as US prime (corn fed). The tour ended with ice cream at an adorable longstanding shop run by a grandmother. We learned that ice cream was brought to Argentina by the Italian immigrants.We really enjoyed learning more about Argentina and the food from our guides. We also enjoyed meeting the other tourists. Importantly, our guides recommended a speakeasy for cocktails, Floreria Atlantico which was one of the other highlights of our South American adventure.

Eat the best, on the tour and beyond. The food on our tour was excellent, but the guidance was invaluable. I'd recommend it to anyone visiting the city, especially at the start of the trip. The tour itself is casual and fun, and the restaurants visited all served delicious food. But the recommendations from our guides turned out to be the most valuable. My girlfriend and I never had a disappointing meal again in the city after learning the best dishes to order.

Cool concept!. I'd never heard of a tour like this till another guest at my hotel recommended it at breakfast, but it makes absolute sense for Buenos Aires.There is a big underground dining scene in the city and a lot of them don't know how (or don't want to?) to market tourists, but in my short trip seem to have the best food in town. The food tour takes you to local secrets to try food, learn a little about the dining culture and meet other travelers. The guide Santiago was spot on with all his recommendations making my Argentina trip especially memorable.

An afternoon of great steak and wine. What's not to love about this tour? Four stops to try top notch local foods.Homemade chorizo sandwich, traditional sauces, fresh baked enpanadas, two cuts of amazing steak, grilled provolone cheese and high end wine.I forgot the artesanal ice cream made that day!!

Start with this tour!. My boyfriend and I did the parilla tour on our final afternoon in Buenos Aires, and regret not doing it right at the beginning of our 5 days in the city. The guides taught us all about how and what to order in Argentina, about the local culture and traditions, and best of all the best spots to eat and drink. The price for this tour is obviously more expensive than the cost of the food you eat (all great by the way), but I'm sure we could have saved hundreds of dollars using all of their tips and connections had we done it earlier on.Thank you!!

Delightful introduction to Buenos Aires. David and Santiago took our small group on a delightful tour of Palermo's little-known eateries. The high point was the closed-door parilla restaurant that had superb grilled meats and an entirely local (other than our group) clientele. David is very knowledgeable about the city, its food and the local history. A bonus was the cheat-sheet they handed to everyone recommending other foodie experiences. Highly recommended.

Fantastic, fun tour. We did the San Telmo tour at the start of our trip. I highly recommend you do the same. We were able to meet lots of friendly vacationers from 4 different countries and enjoy traditional Porteno cuisine together. The guides were extremely knowledgeable and took pains to explain the food, and the history of each spot we visited. I liked that it was about two hours, because we used their recommendations to walk around the rest of that area of the city, and made sure to hit all their favorite spots until we were ready to return to our hotel. Definitely a must-do, and I'll recommend this tour to all of my friends who travel to BA.

Good Local Food Experience. If you're looking for a chance to try restaurants off the beaten path and not in tour guidebooks, I'd recommend this tour. This is not a five start wine and food pairing tour. Rather it is a chance to eat authentic food in interesting neighborhoods that you likely wouldn't find on your own. The guides were very nice, easy to talk to and provided good recommendations for places to try on your own after the tour. I'd recommend taking this tour in the beginning of your vacation so you can use the knowledge on food/neighborhoods for the rest of your stay. David, Santiago and Claudia were a pleasure to meet and spend time with.

Awesome tour!. We did the food tour in Palermo and it was a great day. Highly recommended. The places they take you are authentic (the main Parrilla was a secret restaurant available only to the locals and people who "know someone") Santiago and David were excellent guides and had great advice for other things to do in the city. Well worth it!

Authentic cuisine experience. It was great experience in Buenos Aires! On Parrilla Tours to San Telmo and Palermo (I recommend take these two tours) I tasted a lot of different dishes and drinks at authentic argentinian restaurants and other places. It was nice alternative from buzzers (also good) recomended in TripAdvisor. My guides were wonderful - two guys and girl, everyone speaking very good english (it's big advantage, in Buenos Aires are not many people whose is talking english). They were very kind, chatty and helpful - also in other stuff like sightseeing the city in details. Great experience to know history and nowadays life in Buenos Aires, bon apetit!

They know history, people and food. One American ex-patriot who has been in country for many years, and one local. They brought a lot of understanding to our night of enjoying some secret corners of Argentina's great food culture. You'll enjoy their services.

Wonderful afternoon. We spent the afternoon with David and Santiago and had a great time. We tried lots of local foods, learned about empanadas, steak & Malbec, got to ask loads of questions and met some other lovely people. We felt so welcome and looked after and just enjoyed wandering around the gorgeous streets in the beautiful sunshine learning about the food. A relaxed and fun few hours, thanks guys!

Fantastic.... Great food and great company. David and Santiago are the best. The tour was thoughtful, informative and obviously delicious. What I enjoyed most was the laid back vibe. It didn't feel over or underdone which meant everyone relaxed, chatted and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. We actually had to reschedule at the last minute because my husband was getting over a stomach bug and it was absolutely effortless. David and Santiago clearly know the city and choose their spots with care. They took us to a 'Secret Parilla' that was not open to the public. The steak was better than what we had at the nicest restaurant in Mendoza. All around a great experience and value for the money. Don't miss this.

More than a lunch. The Parrilla Tour was a highlight of our stay in buenos aires. The restaurants we visited were so local and places we would probably have been apprehensive to enter on our own since they are not accustomed to having foreigners. Our guide taught us all about AR cuisine and traditions.
